Cam_(singer):
{{short description|American country music singer and songwriter}} {{good article}} {{Infobox person | name = Cam | image = Country singer Cam at Bra Country Concert.jpg | caption = Cam performing live in 2015 | birth_name = Camaron Marvel Ochs{{cite magazine|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/hear-cams-haunting-new-single-burning-house-20150618|title=Hear Cam's Haunting New Hit Single 'Burning House'|last=Shelburne|first=Craig|date=18 June 2015|magazine=[[Rolling Stone]]|access-date=25 June 2015}} | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1984|11|19}} | birth_place = [[Huntington Beach, California]], U.S. | education = [[University of California, Davis]] | other_names = | occupation = {{flat list| * Singer * songwriter }} | years_active = 2010–present | spouse = {{marriage|Adam Weaver
|2016}} | children = 1 | awards = | website = | module = {{Infobox musical artist | embed = yes | genre = [[Country pop]] | instrument = Vocals | label = {{flat list| *Rubber Room *[[Arista Nashville]] *[[RCA Records|RCA]]/[[Thirty Tigers]] }} | website = [http://www.camcountry.com/ camcountry.com] }} }} '''Camaron Marvel Ochs''' (born November 19, 1984), known professionally as '''Cam''', is an American [[country music]] singer and songwriter. She began her career as a songwriter and has composed material for several artists including [[Beyoncé]], [[Sam Smith (singer)|Sam Smith]] and [[Miley Cyrus]]. In 2010, she released her debut studio album ''Heartforward'' on an independent record label. Signing with [[Sony Music Entertainment]], she released her debut major label [[extended play|EP]] in March 2015, ''[[Welcome to Cam Country]]'', followed by the studio album ''[[Untamed (Cam album)|Untamed]]'' later that same year. Her third album was ''[[The Otherside (album)|The Otherside]]'', released on [[Thirty Tigers|Triple Tigers]] in 2020. Her second single "[[Burning House]]" is her most commercially successful, peaking at the number two position on ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' [[Hot Country Songs]] and [[Country Airplay]]. Spurred by airplay on ''[[The Bobby Bones Show]]'', the song received widespread acclaim, including a Best Country Solo Performance nomination at the [[58th Annual Grammy Awards]] and a Triple Platinum certification by the [[Recording Industry Association of America]] (RIAA). ==Early life== Cam was born on November 19, 1984, in [[Huntington Beach, California]],{{cite news|last1=Rocha|first1=Michael James|title=Country singer Cam on her musical journey — from Oceanside to Nashville to the Grammys|url=http://www.sandiegouniontribune.com/entertainment/music/sd-et-music-cam-20171127-story.html|access-date=29 November 2017|newspaper=The San Diego Union-Tribune|date=November 28, 2017}} and was raised in [[Lafayette, California]], a suburb in the [[San Francisco Bay Area]].{{cite news|last1=Malone|first1=Dana|title=Pathway to a record deal: Hard work, circumstance and originality take Cam Ochs 'Down The Road'|url=http://sportsandentertainmentnashville.com/pathway-to-a-record-deal-hard-work-circumstance-and-originality-take-camaron-ochs-down-the-road/|access-date=22 April 2015|publisher=Sports and Entertainment Nashville|date=5 September 2014}} She also spent time in [[Oceanside, California]], where her grandparents operated a [[ranch]]. They helped develop Cam's appreciation for country music, listening to and performing it regularly.{{cite magazine|last1=Dauphin|first1=Chuck|title=Welcome To Cam Country: Arista Nashville Singer Has a Short Name, Potentially Long Career|url=https://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/the-615/6531920/welcome-to-cam-country-arista-nashville-singer-has-a-short-name|access-date=22 April 2015|magazine=Billboard|date=16 April 2015}} Pursuing music throughout high school and college, she sang in various choral groups.{{cite news|last1=Schadewald|first1=Amber|title=Oakland's Camaron Ochs may inspire folk-pop Barbie|url=http://www.sfbg.com/noise/2010/03/16/oaklands-camaron-ochs-may-inspire-folk-pop-barbie|access-date=22 April 2015|publisher=San Francisco Bay Guardian|date=16 March 2010}} This included performing in the Contra Costa Children's Chorus, where she learned to sing in 14 languages. She attended the [[University of California, Davis]] as an [[undergraduate education|undergraduate student]], studying psychology.{{cite magazine|last1=Roland|first1=Tom|title=Country Singer Cam Dreams Up a Smoldering Ballad With 'Burning House'|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/country/6633599/country-singer-cam-dreams-up-a-smoldering-ballad-with-burning-house|magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]|access-date=28 December 2015}} There, she formed an all-female collegiate [[a cappella]] group called [[The Spokes]] and learned to play the [[guitar]] while studying abroad in the [[Netherlands]]. She developed confidence in playing the instrument on a trip to [[Nepal]]. Taking residency in a rural mountain community, she lived for several weeks with limited electricity and basic needs; in addition, she developed a friendship with various Canadian musicians and started playing the guitar more consistently. In a 2010 interview, Cam stated that she grew more confident in playing once from the trip. Following college, she sporadically performed music but mostly pursued other interests. This included work in research labs, including one at [[Stanford University]]. Yet she remained conflicted about the choices she made.{{cite news|last1=Ryan|first1=Patrick|title=On the Verge: Cam|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/life/music/ontheverge/2015/11/01/on-the-verge-cam-burning-house/74596536/|newspaper=[[USA Today]]|access-date=28 December 2015}} A meeting with a college professor influenced Cam's choice to embark on a full-fledged music career. The professor said to her, "Just picture yourself at 80 years old. Looking back at your life, what would you regret not doing: music or psychology?'"{{cite magazine|last1=Hight|first1=Jewly|title=Why 'Burning House' Singer Cam Gave Up Psychology for Country Music|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/magazine-feature/6708058/cam-burning-house-women-country-music-psychology|magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]|access-date=28 December 2015}} ==Career== ===2010–2014: Early beginnings=== In 2010, Cam released her debut studio album titled ''Heartforward'' via the independent Rubber Room label. Credited to her full name of Camaron Ochs, the album contained contemporary [[pop music|pop]] songs.{{cite web|last1=Deming|first1=Mark|title=Cam: Biography and History|url=http://www.allmusic.com/artist/cam-mn0003380333/biography|website=[[Allmusic]]|access-date=28 December 2015}} Amber Schadewald of the ''[[San Francisco Bay Guardian]]'' called the album a brand of [[Folk rock|folk pop]] that "is light and sweet, with genuine lyrics that ask listeners to live with their 'heartforward'". Songs written for the project were based on experiences from her trip to Nepal. She promoted ''Heartforward'' through performances in [[Oakland, California|Oakland]] and [[San Francisco, California]], including shows at the Stork Club and Mama Buzz. Cam soon moved to [[Los Angeles, California]], and began collaborating with songwriter and producer [[Tyler Johnson (music)|Tyler Johnson]]. She recorded some demos with Johnson in an attempt to attract [[Faith Hill]], eventually leading to the recordings being heard by [[Tim McGraw]]'s manager. Her song "Fall Madly in Love with You" was chosen as a track for ''[[Cut to Impress]]'', the 2013 debut album from [[Maggie Rose]].{{cite web|title=Yes they Cam|url=http://hitsdailydouble.com/news&id=295480|website=HitsDailyDouble|publisher=Hits Digital Ventures|access-date=October 7, 2015|date=April 10, 2015}}{{cite news|last1=Radloff|first1=Jessica|title=Here's What Really Happened Behind the Scenes at the ACM Awards Last Night|url=http://www.glamour.com/entertainment/blogs/obsessed/2015/04/acm-awards-video-photos-red-carpet|access-date=22 April 2015|publisher=Glamour Magazine|date=20 April 2015}} [[Miley Cyrus]] also recorded one of Cam's songs, "Maybe You're Right", on her 2013 album ''[[Bangerz]]''.{{cite news|last1=Lindqvist|first1=Stefan|title=Camaron Ochs sjunger med Helsingborgsband|url=http://www.hd.se/noje/2013/11/30/camaron-ochs-sjunger-med-helsingborgsband/|access-date=22 April 2015|publisher=HD.se|date=30 November 2013|language=sv}} The success of these songs led her to move to [[Nashville, Tennessee]]; there, began writing music for other artists, turning down a publishing deal in attempt to prove herself on her own.{{cite news|title=Cameron Ochs keeps it country with rootsy, organic debut|url=http://forthecountryrecord.com/2014/02/12/cameron-ochs-keeps-it-country-with-rootsy-organic-debut-review/|access-date=22 April 2015|publisher=For The Country Record|date=12 February 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150413063846/http://forthecountryrecord.com/2014/02/12/cameron-ochs-keeps-it-country-with-rootsy-organic-debut-review/|archive-date=13 April 2015|url-status=dead}} She launched a [[Kickstarter]] campaign in 2013 to produce 10 songs with Johnson.{{cite news|last1=Inglis|first1=Nicole|title=Country star on the rise with support from Steamboat locals|url=http://www.steamboattoday.com/news/2012/dec/19/country-star-rise-support-steamboat-locals/|access-date=22 April 2015|publisher=Steamboat Today|date=20 December 2012}} The campaign was supported by producer [[Jeff Bhasker]], known best for his work with artists that include [[Beyoncé]], [[Fun (band)|fun.]], [[Bruno Mars]], and [[Pink (singer)|P!nk]]. The same year Cam toured Denmark and Sweden with [[Helsingborg]] band Karavan, having previously collaborated with Anders Mouridsen of the group while in Los Angeles. Cam released a [[single (music)|single]] in 2013 titled "Down This Road" with the encouragement of manager Lindsay Marias. Through a photo posted on [[Instagram]], local radio director Michael Bryan discovered the song and played it on the air. According to Cam, radio airplay of the single helped her choose which label she wanted to sign to. Ultimately, she chose to meet with [[Doug Morris]], the director of [[Sony Music Entertainment]]. She flew to the label's headquarters in [[New York City]] to meet with him. Using only an [[acoustic guitar]], she sang a song she had already been developing, "[[Burning House]]". Morris started humming along to the chorus and stated, "This is the reason why I got into the music business." He would later ask her to perform the song at the [[Songwriters Hall of Fame]] ceremony.{{cite web|last1=Rau|first1=Nate|title=Sony Music CEO Doug Morris touts Nashville up-and-comers|url=http://www.tennessean.com/story/entertainment/music/2015/07/24/sony-music-ceo-doug-morris-touts-nashville-up-and-comers/30641039/|website=[[The Tennessean]]|access-date=28 December 2015}} She was soon signed to Sony's country division, [[Arista Nashville]] in 2014{{cite magazine|title=Tomorrow's Hits: The Avener's 'Fade Out Lines,' Cam and Young Rising Sons|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/chart-beat/6472726/tomorrow-hits-avener-cam-young-rising-sons|access-date=22 April 2015|magazine=Billboard|date=13 February 2015}} and toured nationally with [[Dan + Shay]] that same year on their ''Where It All Began'' tour. ===2015–2017: Breakthrough=== In early 2015, [[Arista Nashville]] released Cam's first single for them, "[[My Mistake (Cam song)|My Mistake]]". In March, the song debuted at No. 58 on the ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' [[Country Airplay]] chart.{{cite magazine|last1=Jessen|first1=Wade|title=Blackberry Smoke's 'Roses' Blooms at No. 1 on Top Country Albums|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/chart-beat/6479936/blackberry-smoke-top-country-albums|access-date=22 April 2015|magazine=Billboard|date=19 February 2015}} The song peaked at number 52 only a few weeks later.{{cite web|title=New Country Adds|url=http://www.country103.ca/new-music-added/|website=Country 103|access-date=28 December 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160106231408/http://www.country103.ca/new-music-added/|archive-date=2016-01-06|url-status=dead}} Still using her full name (Camaron Ochs) during the single's promotion, she ultimately shortened it to "Cam" because some people found her last name "too hard to pronounce". "My Mistake" preceded Cam's debut [[extended play|EP]], ''[[Welcome to Cam Country]]'', released in March 2015. It contained four songs, with Bhasker and Johnson serving as producers.{{cite web|last1=Allers|first1=Hannahlee|title=Cam Releases Debut EP|url=http://theboot.com/cam-welcome-to-cam-country-ep/|website=The Boot|date=12 April 2015 |access-date=28 December 2015}}{{cite web|url=http://www.sonymusicnashville.com/press/cam/97966/arista-nashville-recording-artist-cam-reveals-debut-ep-exclusively-spotify|title=Arista Nashville Recording Artist Cam Reveals Debut EP, Exclusively on Spotify|work=Sony Music Nashville|access-date=25 June 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150626130318/http://www.sonymusicnashville.com/press/cam/97966/arista-nashville-recording-artist-cam-reveals-debut-ep-exclusively-spotify|archive-date=26 June 2015|url-status=dead}} It peaked at No. 31 on the ''Billboard'' [[Top Country Albums]] chart, No. 88 on the [[Billboard 200]], and No. 5 on the [[Top Heatseekers]] survey.{{cite web|title=''Welcome to Cam Country'' - Cam: Awards|url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/welcome-to-cam-country-mw0002836605/awards|website=[[Allmusic]]|access-date=28 December 2015}} "Burning House" served as her next single. She performed the song live on the radio program ''[[The Bobby Bones Show]]'', which attracted and fueled attention to the song. [[Sony Music Entertainment]], of which Arista Nashville is a division, then arranged a meeting and decided to release the track as a single on June 16, 2015, after the song had initial success on the [[iTunes]] charts. "Burning House" became a top-five hit on the ''Billboard'' [[Hot Country Songs|country songs]] and country airplay charts.{{cite magazine|last1=Asker|first1=Jim|title=Cam & Emily Ann Roberts' Versions of 'Burning House' Are Both in the Hot Country Songs Top Five|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/chart-beat/6820766/cam-emily-ann-roberts-burning-house-charts|magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]|access-date=28 December 2015}} It also was the highest-selling female country song of 2015, selling more than 500,000 copies in the United States.{{cite magazine|last1=Leahey|first1=Andrew|title=Watch Cam Cap Off Smoldering Year With Live 'Burning House'|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/watch-cam-cap-off-smoldering-year-with-live-burning-house-20151216|magazine=[[Rolling Stone]]|access-date=28 December 2015}} In addition the song received nominations at the 2016 [[Grammy Awards]], [[Academy of Country Music Awards]], and [[Country Music Association Awards]].{{cite magazine|title=Cam, "Burning House" - 25 Best Country Songs of 2015|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/lists/25-best-country-songs-of-2015-20151214/cam-burning-house-20151214|magazine=[[Rolling Stone]]|access-date=28 December 2015}} In January 2022 "Burning House" was certified triple-platinum by the [[Recording Industry Association of America]] (RIAA). The success of the song led to the release of her first Arista Nashville album ''[[Untamed (Cam album)|Untamed]]'' on December 11, 2015. Also produced largely by Bhasker and Johnson, it consisted of 11 tracks all co-written by Cam, including all of the songs from the EP.{{cite web|last1=Reuter|first1=Annie|title=Cam Announces Title, Release Date for Major Label Debut Read More: Cam Announces Title, Release Date for Major Label Debut|url=http://tasteofcountry.com/cam-debut-album-untamed/|website=[[Taste of Country]]|date=2 November 2015 |access-date=28 December 2015}} It debuted at number two on the Top Country Albums chart and was the highest-selling debut country studio album of 2015. ''Rolling Stone'' ranked the album at number 15 on their list of the "40 Best Country Albums of 2015". The magazine commented, "For an artist at the start of career, Cam already sounds like one of the most secure in the game." "[[Mayday (Cam song)|Mayday]]" was released as the album's third single in February 2016.{{cite web|last1=Carr|first1=Courtney|title=Cam Selects 'Mayday' as New Single [LISTEN]|url=http://theboot.com/cam-mayday-song-single/|website=The Boot|date=27 January 2016 |access-date=20 February 2016}} It was a minor Top 40 hit on the country charts, peaking at number 36 on ''Billboard'' Country Airplay. In October 2017, Cam announced a new single titled [[Diane (Cam song)|"Diane"]].{{cite web|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/country/news/hear-cams-jolene-inspired-new-song-diane-w510372|title=Hear Cam's Supercharged, 'Jolene'-Inspired New Song 'Diane'|last=Betts|first=Stephen L.|date=October 27, 2017|work=Rolling Stone Country|access-date=27 October 2017}} She promoted the song with several live performances including on [[Good Morning America]],{{cite web|url=https://www.countryliving.com/life/entertainment/a19681578/cam-diane-song/|title=Watch Dolly Parton Surprise Country Singer Cam On 'Good Morning America'|last=Matthews|first=Lauren|date=4 April 2018|work=Country Living|access-date=2 January 2019}} ''[[The Late Late Show with James Corden]]'',{{cite magazine|url=https://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/country/8343549/late-late-show-cam-diane|title=Cam Gives Mesmerizing Performance of 'Diane' on 'The Late Late Show'|last=Cummings-Grady|first=Mackenzie|date=17 April 2018|magazine=Billboard|access-date=2 January 2019}} and as a duet with a contestant on [[American Idol (season 16)|season 16 of ''American Idol'']].{{cite web|url=http://theboot.com/cam-american-idol-effie-passero-diane-shannon-ohara-burning-house/|title=Cam Duets with 'American Idol' Contestants on 'Diane,' 'Burning House'|last=Stefano|first=Angela|date=17 April 2018|work=The Boot|access-date=2 January 2019}} In April 2018, "Diane" was added to the [[BBC Radio 2]] A-list and hit No. 1 on iTunes for 5 weeks. Also in 2017, Cam, along with [[Sam Smith (singer)|Sam Smith]] and Tyler Johnson, co-wrote the song "Palace" for Smith's 2017 album ''[[The Thrill of It All (Sam Smith album)|The Thrill of It All]]'' and providing background vocals and guitar to the track.{{cite web|url=https://people.com/country/cam-wrote-sam-smith-song-we-had-same-heartache/|title=Country Star Cam on Writing a Song for Sam Smith's New Album: We Had the 'Same Heartache'|last=Nelson|first=Jeff|date=3 November 2017|work=People|access-date=2 January 2019}} The song saw international success and was highlighted in the Holiday "Sway" commercial for [[Apple Inc.|Apple]] which led to its reaching No. 1 on the Billboard Top TV Commercials Chart.{{cite magazine|url=https://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/chart-beat/8093860/sam-smith-palace-apple-ad-top-tv-commercials-chart-number-one|title=Sam Smith's 'Palace' Hits No. 1 on Top TV Commercials Chart for December|last=Zellner|first=Xander|date=11 January 2018|magazine=Billboard|access-date=2 January 2019}} The widespread embrace of "Palace" included much international success, specifically in [[Japan]], where Smith performed the song on multiple TV talk shows. Cam opened for Smith on the Summer US leg of his 2018 The Thrill Of It All Tour.{{cite magazine|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-country/cam-joins-sam-smiths-thrill-of-it-all-tour-629146/|title=Cam Joins Sam Smith's Thrill of It All Tour|last=Betts|first=Stephen L.|date=7 June 2018|magazine=Rolling Stone|access-date=2 January 2019}} Cam has also shared the stage with [[Tim McGraw]] and [[Faith Hill]] on their [[Soul2Soul: The World Tour|Soul2Soul Tour]]{{cite magazine|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-country/tim-mcgraw-faith-hills-soul2soul-tour-taps-devin-dawson-caitlyn-smith-127866/|title=Tim McGraw, Faith Hill's Soul2Soul Tour Taps Devin Dawson, Caitlyn Smith|last=Parton|first=Chris|date=19 March 2018|magazine=Rolling Stone|access-date=2 January 2019}} as well as [[Harry Styles]].{{cite web|url=https://people.com/country/harry-styles-invited-cam-open-nashville-concert-better-than-hype/|title=Harry Styles Invited Country Star Cam to Open His Nashville Show: 'He's Even Better Than All the Hype'|last=Nelson|first=Jeff|date=29 September 2017|work=People|access-date=2 January 2019}} ===2018–present: Transition to RCA === In July 2018, Cam released "Road to Happiness"{{cite web|url=http://tasteofcountry.com/cam-road-to-happiness/|title=Cam Ponders the Real Meaning of Joy in 'Road to Happiness'|last=Whitaker|first=Sterling|date=13 July 2018|work=Taste of Country|access-date=2 January 2019}} and parted ways with Arista Nashville.{{cite magazine |title=Cam Signs with Nashville's Triple Tiers Label in Partnership with RCA New York |url=https://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/country/9410902/cam-signs-nashville-triple-tigers-partnership-rca-new-york |access-date=June 29, 2020 |magazine=Billboard}} In 2019, she provided vocals for [[Diplo]]'s song "[[So Long (Diplo song)|So Long]]" for his ''[[Diplo Presents Thomas Wesley, Chapter 1: Snake Oil]]'' album.{{Cite magazine|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-news/diplo-cam-so-long-thomas-wesley-828677/|title=Song You Need to Know: Diplo and Cam, 'So Long'|last=Freeman|first=Jon|date=2019-05-02|magazine=Rolling Stone|language=en-US|access-date=2020-02-13}} On June 29, 2020, it was announced that Cam had signed a new partnership for radio promotion with Nashville-based [[Triple Tigers]] in a joint venture with her label [[RCA Records]]. "Classic" was released on July 17, 2020, as her first country radio single since "Diane" in 2017. Her critically acclaimed sophomore album, ''[[The Otherside (album)|The Otherside]]'', was released on October 30, 2020.{{Cite web |title=The Otherside by Cam |url=https://music.apple.com/nz/album/the-otherside/1523527625}} For this release, she once again enlisted producers [[Tyler Johnson (musician)|Tyler Johnson]] ([[Harry Styles]], [[Miley Cyrus]]) and [[Jeff Bhasker]] ([[Kanye West]], [[Alicia Keys]]). The record featured the international Jolene-in-reverse hit “[[Diane (Cam song)|Diane]],” the song “Till There's Nothing Left,” plus songwriting from [[Avicii]], [[Harry Styles]], [[Jack Antonoff]], and [[Sam Smith]]. {{Cite magazine|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-country/cam-till-theres-nothing-left-952115/|title=Cam Addresses Sex and Swagger on New Song, 'Till There's Nothing Left'|last=Freeman|first=Jon|date=2020-02-13|magazine=Rolling Stone|language=en-US|access-date=2020-02-13}}{{cite web |title=Cam preps "magical" new song, "Redwood Tree" |url=http://www.hotcountry931.com/2020/05/cam-preps-magical-new-song-redwood-tree/ |website=Hot Country 931 |access-date=28 May 2020}} In 2024, she contributed songwriting, production and backing vocals for [[Beyoncé]]'s ''[[Cowboy Carter]]'' album (“American Requiem,” “Amen,” “Protector,” “Tyrant,” “Daughter”).{{cite web | url=https://variety.com/2024/music/news/cam-beyonce-cowboy-carter-writing-production-1235963667/ | title=Singer-Songwriter Cam Discusses Working on Five Tracks for Beyoncé's Cowboy Carter: She's Just Such a Creative Genius | date=8 April 2024 }}{{cite web |title=Cam Post on Twitter |url=https://twitter.com/camcountry/status/1773788015346974744 |website=twitter.com |publisher=X Corp. |access-date=2024-04-07}} ==Artistry== Cam was exposed to classic country music at an early age from the time spent on her grandparents' ranch. They introduced her to the musical sounds of [[Patsy Cline]], [[Bonnie Raitt]] and [[Willie Nelson]]. She was largely influenced by the vocal phrasing of Cline and [[Ray Charles]]. She also developed an appreciation for [[the Chicks]] and the [[Indigo Girls]], commenting that she was "so into those female harmonies". She additionally cites [[Bob Dylan]], [[Joni Mitchell]], and [[Randy Newman]] as influences on her songwriting style. Although she has a variety of musical influences, Cam stated that country music is where she felt most connected to. In a 2015 interview with ''[[Rolling Stone]]'', she explained her reasoning: "I grew up singing in a lot of different languages and a lot of world music choirs, so I have a lot of musical influences. But the songwriting structure of country music is the standard in my mind. ... That structure seems to feel the most homey to me."{{cite magazine|title=Cam - 10 New Country Artists You Need to Know: Spring 2015|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/lists/10-new-country-artists-you-need-to-know-spring-2015-20150505/cam-20150505|magazine=[[Rolling Stone]]|access-date=28 December 2015}} ==Personal life== In September 2015, Cam became engaged to Adam Weaver, a business broker with First Choice Business Brokers in Nashville.{{cite web|last1=McClellan|first1=Laura|title=Cam Shows Off New Bling|url=http://tasteofcountry.com/cam-engaged/|website=Taste of Country|date=9 September 2015 |access-date=22 July 2016}} In October 2016, the couple married in a small ceremony in a California desert.{{cite web|last1=Anderson|first1=Danielle|title=See Cam's Stunning Wedding Album!|url=http://people.com/country/cam-wedding-album-marries-adam-weaver/|website=People|access-date=11 October 2016}} In December 2019, she gave birth to her first child, Lucy. Shortly after giving birth, Cam posted on social media that she was a "breech at 39wks, a next-day c-section (ouch) & here we are... three of us now."{{cite magazine |last1=Iasimone |first1=Ashley |title=Cam Gives Birth to Baby Lucy Marvel: See the Photos |url=https://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/country/8546960/cam-baby-birth-announcement |magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] |access-date=24 February 2020}} Cam is a vocal advocate for music education and inclusion. She spoke on the psychology of music in her 2017 [[TEDx talk|TEDx Talk]] at the University of Nevada.{{cite magazine|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-country/5-things-we-learned-from-cams-tedx-talk-193313/|title=5 Things We Learned From Cam's TEDx Talk|last=Parton|first=Chris|date=7 March 2017|magazine=Rolling Stone|access-date=2 January 2019}} Cam is on the [[Academy of Country Music]] (ACM) Board and was invited to join [[The Recording Academy]]'s Task Force on Diversity and Inclusion in 2018.{{cite web|url=https://www.grammy.com/grammys/news/recording-academy-names-diversity-and-inclusion-task-force-members/|title= Recording Academy Names Diversity And Inclusion Task Force Members|date=9 May 2018|work=Grammy.com|access-date=2 January 2019}} In 2018, Cam joined the speaker list on [[Hello Sunshine (company)|Hello Sunshine]] x Together Live's touring event{{cite web|url=http://togetherlive.com/about/|title= Our Stories Travel|access-date=2 January 2019}} ==Discography== {{main|Cam discography}} '''Studio albums''' * ''Heartforward'' (2010) * ''[[Untamed (Cam album)|Untamed]]'' (2015) * ''[[The Otherside (album)|The Otherside]]'' (2020) ==Awards and nominations== {|class="wikitable plainrowheaders" |- !Year !Recipient/Nominated work !Association !Award !Result !{{abbr|Ref.|Reference}} |- |rowspan="8"| 2016 |rowspan="4"| "[[Burning House]]" |[[58th Annual Grammy Awards|Grammy Awards]] |[[Grammy Award for Best Country Solo Performance|Best Country
